messages.content: You are an AI assistant that helps people find information. You will receive a task and think step by step. Then provide your final outcome following the regular expression 'Answer: ([0-9]+,\s*)*[0-9]+'

Imagine a house with 21 rooms. Room 1 is connected to rooms 21, 5, 24, 9, 4, and 13. Room 2 is connected to rooms 22, 6, 10, 11, 7, and 14. Room 3 is connected to rooms 35, 41, 23, 12, 8, and 20. Room 4 is connected to rooms 13, 21, 5, 24, and 9. Room 5 is connected to rooms 24, 9, 13, and 21. Room 6 is connected to rooms 24, 10, 11, 7, and 14. Room 7 is connected to rooms 14, 22, 10, and 11. Room 8 is connected to rooms 20, 35, 41, 23, and 12. Room 9 is connected to rooms 13, 21, and 41. Room 10 is connected to rooms 11, 14, and 22. Room 11 is connected to rooms 14 and 22. Room 12 is connected to rooms 20, 35, 41, and 23. Room 13 is connected to rooms 21, and 24. Room 14 is connected to rooms 22. Room 20 is connected to rooms 35, 41, and 23. Room 21 is connected to room 24. Room 22 is connected to room 23. Room 23 is connected to rooms 35. Room 35 is connected to room 41. What is the shortest path from room 13 to room 12? Please list the room numbers in order, separated by commas.

Format:
[13,1,2,3] => room numbers list separated by commas (0-9,)
[1,3,5,7,8] => single/multiple room number list separated by space (0-9, (,[12] => space or single/multiple number list separated by space)
[0,3][2,5] => either 0-3, 2-5 or 0-3,2-5 or any number submission format
The shortest code after 1 week wins.
Your AI assistant is expected to answer in a few seconds. If your AI assistant can't answer, please provide an example of how it thinks after 5 minutes. Your AI assistant is expected to pass all the test cases - the answers of the other rooms don't matter.

Since the last question about the sexiest beer asked I have had a good idea.
What is the most wanted job in the tech world?
Any hints would be welcome!

JavaScript, a scripting language of the web browser. Just last week, I wrote a text colordescription using JavaScript at work. I found this interesting, and there are many similarities between this form of code and C++.
